instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used on identifying the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch?
Output: Past study used Fourier transform near-infrared (FT-NIR) spectroscopy on identifying the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed to select efficient spectral subintervals and characteristic wavelengths on identifying the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods employed were the synergy interval partial least squares (siPLS) method and the iteratively retains informative variables (IRIV) algorithm.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the identification of geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch, and how far can this metric go in determining the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the identification model in determining the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch is the identification rate. The text states that the identification rate of the validation set is 100% based on extreme learning machine (ELM). This means that the model was able to accurately identify the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch in all cases in the validation set. Therefore, the identification rate metric indicates a high level of accuracy in determining the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch using the FT-NIR spectroscopy technique combined with multivariate calibration.

instruction: What machine learning model was used for the identification of the validation set on using FT-NIR spectroscopy to identify the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch?
Output: The machine learning model used for the identification of the validation set was the extreme learning machine (ELM).

instruction: Can the FT-NIR spectroscopy analysis technique coupled with multivariate calibration be considered superior to traditional methods in identifying the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch?
Output: Yes, the FT-NIR spectroscopy analysis technique coupled with multivariate calibration can be considered superior to traditional methods in identifying the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch. The experimental results show that the identification rate of the validation set is 100% based on the extreme learning machine (ELM). This indicates that the FT-NIR spectroscopy technique combined with multivariate calibration is an excellent choice for discriminating the geographical origins of Radix puerariae starch.
